401(k) , URL: /wiki/401(k): Capital gains, dividends, and interest within account incur no tax liability.
Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): Capital gains, dividends, and interest within account incur no tax liability.
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: Capital gains, dividends, and interest within account incur no tax liability.
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: Capital gains, dividends, and interest within account incur no tax liability.

401(k) , URL: /wiki/401(k): sole proprietor , URL: /wiki/Sole_proprietorship
Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): sole proprietor , URL: /wiki/Sole_proprietorship
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: Individual sets up this plan.
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: Individual sets up this plan.

401(k) , URL: /wiki/401(k): Employee contribution limit of $20,500/yr for under 50; $27,000/yr for age 50 or above in 2022; limits are a total of pre-tax Traditional 401(k) and Roth 401(k) contributions.[4] Total employee (including after-tax Traditional 401(k)) and employer combined contributions must be lesser of 100% of employee's salary or $58,000 ($64,500 for age 50 or above). There is no income cap for this investment class.
Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): Employee contribution limit of $20,500/yr for under 50; $27,000/yr for age 50 or above in 2022; limits are a total of pre-tax Traditional 401(k) and Roth 401(k) contributions.[4] Total employee (including after-tax Traditional 401(k)) and employer combined contributions must be lesser of 100% of employee's salary or $58,000 ($64,500 for age 50 or above). There is no income cap for this investment class.
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: $6,000/yr for age 49 or below; $7,000/yr for age 50 or above in 2022; limits are total for traditional IRA and Roth IRA contributions combined. Cannot contribute more than annual earned income. For direct contributions to Roth IRAs, contribution limit is reduced in a "phase-out" range, for single MAGI > $129,000 and joint MAGI > $204,000[5] (For this purpose, however, MAGI excludes any Roth conversions.[6]) Contribution limit does not apply to conversions from traditional IRA (or qualified employer plans) to Roth IRA.
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: $6,000/yr for age 49 or below; $7,000/yr for age 50 or above in 2022; limits are total for traditional IRA and Roth IRA contributions combined. Cannot contribute more than annual earned income. For direct contributions to Roth IRAs, contribution limit is reduced in a "phase-out" range, for single MAGI > $129,000 and joint MAGI > $204,000[5] (For this purpose, however, MAGI excludes any Roth conversions.[6]) Contribution limit does not apply to conversions from traditional IRA (or qualified employer plans) to Roth IRA.

Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): Effective limit is higher compared to traditional 401(k) as the contributions are post-tax.
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: Effective limit is higher compared to traditional IRA as the contributions are post-tax.

401(k) , URL: /wiki/401(k): Matching contributions available from some employers.
Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): Matching contributions available through some employers, but they must sit in a pretax account.[7]
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: No matching contributions available.
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: No matching contributions available.

401(k) , URL: /wiki/401(k): Distributions can begin at age 59½ or if owner becomes disabled.
Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): Distributions can begin at age 59½ and the account has been open for at least 5 years, or if owner becomes disabled, with some exceptions.
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: Distributions can begin at age 59½ or if owner becomes disabled.
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: Distributions can begin at age 59½ as long as contributions are "seasoned" (5 years from January 1 of the year the first contribution was made) or owner becomes disabled.

401(k) , URL: /wiki/401(k): Must start withdrawing funds at age 72 unless employee is still employed with employer setting up the 401(k), and not a 5% owner. Penalty is 50% of minimum distribution.
Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): Must start withdrawing funds at age 72 unless employee is still employed with employer setting up the 401(k), and not a 5% owner. Penalty is 50% of minimum distribution.
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: Must start withdrawing funds at age 72. Penalty is 50% of minimum distribution.
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: None.

401(k) , URL: /wiki/401(k): When still employed with employer setting up the 401(k), loans may be available depending upon the plan, not more than 50% of balance or $50,000.
Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): When still employed with employer setting up the 401(k), loans may be available depending upon the plan, not more than 50% of balance or $50,000.
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: No
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: No

401(k) , URL: /wiki/401(k): Generally no when still employed with employer setting up the 401(k). Otherwise, 10% penalty plus taxes. There are some exceptions to this penalty.[8]
Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): Generally no when still employed with employer setting up the 401(k). Otherwise, taxes on the earnings, plus 10% penalty on taxable part of distribution and taxable part of unseasoned conversions. There are some exceptions to this penalty.
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: 10% penalty plus taxes for distributions before age 59½ with exceptions.
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: Principal of contributions and seasoned conversions can be withdrawn at any time without tax or penalty. Additional amounts are subject to normal income taxes and 10% penalty if not qualified distributions.

401(k) , URL: /wiki/401(k): Purchase of primary residence and avoidance of foreclosure or eviction of primary residence, subject to 10% penalty, if hardship withdrawals are available in the plan.[9]
Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): If your plan permits distributions from accounts because of hardship, you may choose to receive a hardship distribution from your designated Roth account. The hardship distribution will consist of a pro-rata share of earnings and basis and the earnings portion will be included in gross income unless you have had the designated Roth account for 5 years and are either disabled or over age 59 ½.
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: Can withdraw up to $10,000 for a first time home purchase down payment with stipulations.
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: Up to $10,000 can be used for primary home down payment. Must have held Roth IRA for a minimum of 5 years. Must not have owned a home in previous 24 months. House must be owned by IRA owner or direct linear ancestors or descendants.

401(k) , URL: /wiki/401(k): Payment of secondary educational expenses in last 12 months for employee, spouse, or dependents, subject to 10% penalty, if hardship withdrawals are available in the plan.[9]
Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): If your plan permits distributions from accounts because of hardship, you may choose to receive a hardship distribution from your designated Roth account. The hardship distribution will consist of a pro-rata share of earnings and basis and the earnings portion will be included in gross income unless you have had the designated Roth account for 5 years and are either disabled or over age 59 ½.
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: Can withdraw for qualified higher education expenses of owner, children, and grandchildren.
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: Can withdraw for qualified higher education expenses of owner, children, and grandchildren.

401(k) , URL: /wiki/401(k): Medical expenses not covered by insurance for employee, spouse, or dependents, subject to 10% penalty, if hardship withdrawals are available in the plan. Medical expenses in excess of 7.5% of your adjusted gross income may be exempt to the 10% penalty.[9]
Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): If your plan permits distributions from accounts because of hardship, you may choose to receive a hardship distribution from your designated Roth account. The hardship distribution will consist of a pro-rata share of earnings and basis and the earnings portion will be included in gross income unless you have had the designated Roth account for 5 years and are either disabled or over age 59 ½.
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: Can withdraw for qualified unreimbursed medical expenses that are more than 7.5% of AGI; medical insurance during period of unemployment; during disability.
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: Can withdraw for qualified unreimbursed medical expenses that are more than 7.5% of AGI; medical insurance during period of unemployment; during disability.

Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k)
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional_IRA
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA

401(k) , URL: /wiki/401(k): Upon termination of employment (or in some plans, even while in service), can be rolled to IRA or Roth IRA. When rolled to a Roth IRA, taxes need to be paid during the year of the conversion.
Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): Cannot be converted to a traditional 401(k), but upon termination of employment (or in some plans, even while in service), can be rolled into Roth IRA.
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: backdoor Roth IRA contributions , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA#Traditional_IRA_conversion_as_a_workaround_to_Roth_IRA_income_limits

401(k) , URL: /wiki/401(k): Can roll over to another employer's 401(k) plan or to a rollover IRA at an independent institution.
Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): Can roll over to another employer's Roth 401(k) plan or to a Roth IRA at an independent institution.
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: Funds can be either transferred to another institution or they can be sent to the owner of the traditional IRA who has 60 days to put the money in another institution in a rollover contribution to another traditional IRA.[10]
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: Funds can be either transferred to another institution or they can be sent to the owner of the traditional IRA who has 60 days to put the money in another institution in a rollover contribution to another traditional IRA.[10]

401(k) , URL: /wiki/401(k): For married persons, federal law dictates that the beneficiary of any form of 401(k) automatically be the surviving spouse. A different party may be named beneficiary, however, provided the surviving-spouse-to-be has consented and the consent is in written form. For single persons, any party may be named beneficiary; however, if no beneficiary is named, then it defaults to the decedent's estate.
Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): For married persons, federal law dictates that the beneficiary of any form of 401(k) automatically be the surviving spouse. A different party may be named beneficiary, however, provided the surviving-spouse-to-be has consented and the consent is in written form. For single persons, any party may be named beneficiary; however, if no beneficiary is named, then it defaults to the decedent's estate.
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: When owner dies, spouse as beneficiary can roll both accounts into one IRA account. Other beneficiaries will be subject to forced distributions (taxable) over a ten-year period. Beneficiaries will not pay estate tax if the inheritance is under the exemption amount.
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: When owner dies, spouse as beneficiary can roll both accounts into one IRA account. Other beneficiaries will be subject to forced distributions (taxable) over a ten-year period. Beneficiaries will not pay estate tax if the inheritance is under the exemption amount.

401(k) , URL: /wiki/401(k): Account is protected from bankruptcy and creditors (with limited exceptions, e.g. IRS).
Roth 401(k) , URL: /wiki/Roth_401(k): Account is protected from bankruptcy and creditors (with limited exceptions, e.g. IRS).
Traditional IRA , URL: /wiki/Traditional: Account is protected from bankruptcy up to $1,362,800.[11] Protection from creditors varies by state (from none to full protection).
Roth IRA , URL: /wiki/Roth_IRA: Account is protected from bankruptcy up to $1,362,800.[11] Protection from creditors varies by state (from none to full protection).
